awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Research Initiation: Social Engagement & Belonging in Academic Makerspaces
awd_abstract_narration:
Academic makerspaces provide students with open access to resources that help them develop their problem solving skills, provide opportunities for collaboration, and encourage experimentation and discovery. However, recent research has shown that many makerspace environments do not readily support all students, create tensions between different student groups, and can sometimes lead to a work environment that feels exclusive and unwelcoming. It is essential that our academic makerspaces are welcoming and that all students feel a sense of belonging and acceptance in these spaces. This project will use the flexible nature of an academic makerspace as the framework to provide students with the opportunity to connect socially in ways that have been shown to increase sense of belonging. This will be accomplished by integrating social engagement activities into a university affiliated makerspace. The engagement activities will be designed to support students’ social and emotional development, which is an essential component to creating culturally competent, well-rounded engineers. Due to the flexible and informal nature of the makerspace environment, it is an ideal place to build and create social connections between students. Makerspaces provide a venue for informal learning and student connection that inspires attributes associated with the professional formation of engineers: creativity, discovery, lifelong learning, teamwork, and critical thinking. This study will lay the foundation for future research that will inform strategies to create a makerspace culture with a focus on supporting all students.

This project aims to increase student sense of belonging in undergraduate engineering students through the integration of social engagement activities into an academic makerspace. The objectives of this project are to (1) strategically integrate social engagement activities that have been shown to contribute to increased sense of belonging and student persistence into an academic makerspace; (2) research the effects of the social engagement activities on student sense of belonging; and (3) increase engineering education research capacity at Western Washington University. The outcomes of this work will lead to identification of best practices for improving student sense of belonging in a makerspace environment. This research will investigate the impact of carefully designed social engagement activities on development of student sense of belonging. Within the recent context of the COVID-19 pandemic, social support and positive sense of belonging have been shown to counter the adverse social emotional effects of the experience. Engagement activities will focus on supporting student social and emotional development, providing peer support, and building awareness of the importance of having all students feel accepted in these spaces. The activities will be designed so that any student can participate regardless of ability level, time availability, or physical location. The research questions that will guide this work are (1) To what extent do students participate in the engagement activities within the makerspace and in which formats, and does this level of engagement vary based on student demographics? and (2) To what extent does participation in the engagement activities lead to an increased sense of belonging? These research questions will be investigated through a communities of practice theoretical framework using a two-year mixed methods research that includes survey development, analysis, student reflections, and focus groups.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

por.por_cntn:
This project explored how social engagement activities in university makerspaces can help engineering students feel more connected to their field of study. Makerspaces are collaborative work areas where students can access tools and equipment for hands-on projects. While these spaces offer great learning opportunities, they can sometimes feel unwelcoming to certain student groups, particularly women and underrepresented minorities. This project aimed to make makerspaces more inclusive by hosting social activities that helped students build connections with their peers in a low-pressure environment.

The project had three main components:

  1. Creating and running social engagement activities in the makerspace
  2. Studying how these activities affected students' sense of belonging
  3. Understanding the experiences of student mentors who led these activities

Over three years, a team of student mentors called "Student Engagement Liaisons" (SELs) organized 36 social events in the makerspace, including craft nights, discussion groups, and workshops. These events were specifically designed to be welcoming to students of all skill levels and backgrounds. The research found that these activities helped students feel more connected to both the makerspace and their engineering department. Notably, women and gender-diverse students reported positive or neutral changes in their sense of belonging after participating in the events.

The study also revealed important insights about the student mentors themselves. The mentors experienced personal and professional growth through leading these activities. They developed leadership skills, gained confidence, and felt empowered to create positive change in their department. Interestingly, male and female mentors approached their roles differently - male mentors tended to focus more on technical improvements and personal development, while female mentors emphasized creating inclusive communities and supporting underrepresented students.

The broader impacts of this project include:

  • Developing effective strategies for making engineering spaces more welcoming to all students
  • Creating a sustainable model for student-led community building initiatives that can be adopted by other universities
  • Contributing to efforts to diversify the engineering workforce by helping traditionally underrepresented students feel more connected to engineering
  • Building a more collaborative and supportive engineering culture that values both technical and social skills

The project's success led to sustained funding from industry to continue these activities beyond the grant period, showing that industry recognizes the value of creating environments where all students can thrive and contribute their unique perspectives. This work provides important insights for universities looking to enhance student engagement and build stronger communities within their engineering programs.

This research demonstrates that thoughtfully designed social activities can help create more inclusive technical spaces, ultimately contributing to a more diverse and welcoming engineering profession. The findings can help other universities develop similar programs to support student belonging and success in engineering.

 

 


Last Modified: 12/16/2024
Modified by: Jill Davishahl
